title: brexit latest theresa may eu northern ireland border deal uk
story: Significant gaps in Theresa May’s new Brexit customs plan for Northern Ireland would lead to the creation of a hard border with the Republic, the European Commission has said.A presentation drawn up by the EU’s negotiating team for member states said the UK’s customs paper, which was released on Thursday, “leaves key questions unanswered”.Officials are particularly worried that the UK plan would not keep Northern Ireland aligned with single market rules, meaning regulatory checks would be needed at the border for goods.They are also concerned at UK proposals to time-limit the proposal until 2021 at the latest, with the presentation asking: “Is this a backstop?”The presentation concludes that the UK proposal “does not cover regulatory controls, leading to a hard border”.Brexit secretary David Davis met with chief negotiator Michel Barnier in Brussels on Monday to discuss progress in the negotiations. The trip is only Mr Davis’s second visit to the de facto EU capital this year, with progress in talks having been slow. The minister declined to speak to the press during the trip.The “backstop solution” is supposed to prevent a hard border from emerging on the island of Ireland no matter what happens. Both sides say they do not want a hard border because the open frontier is part of the Good Friday Agreement, which brought an end to the Troubles.Mr Barnier last week said he was still studying the UK’s proposal and had not rejected it out of hand. When asked why he was doing so if it has such problems, he said: “Because I look at all British proposals in an objective manner.”The UK paper is the product of months of cabinet wrangling over how to temporarily solve the Irish border issue if it cannot be solved by a wider trade deal.&nbspSeparately, the cabinet has still not decided on a single solution for the wider customs agreement between the UK and EU – with two options on the table. Both ideas, “max fac” and “customs partnership” have been rejected out of hand by Brussels.A spokesperson for the European Commission said: “We can confirm that the European Commission chief negotiator Michel Barnier and the secretary of state for exiting the European Union David Davis met this morning here in Brussels where they discussed the latest state of play of the Article 50 negotiations. They touched on issues related to the withdrawal agreement, including the backstop for Ireland-Northern Ireland and the framework for the future relationship.”British officials confirmed a similar line neither side would give more details.Officials on both sides are getting ready for a European Council summit in March where member states will take stock over the state of negotiations so far.A UK Government spokesperson said: “The Prime Minster has been clear that we will never accept a customs border between Northern Ireland and the rest of the United Kingdom.&nbspWe are also committed to maintaining the integrity of our own internal market. That position will not change. The Commission’s proposals did not achieve this, which is why we have put forward our own backstop solutions for customs.“All parties must recall their commitment in the Joint Report to protect the Belfast Agreement in all its parts. Michel Barnier confirmed on Friday that discussions will now continue on our proposal.”or register with your social accountAlready have an account? title: uk manufacturing latest april worst five years office national statistics gdp bank england
story: Output from firms fell 1.4 per cent in the month according to the Office for National Statistics, the worst performance since October 2012UK manufacturing had its worst month in more than five years in April, flying in the face of hopes that the first quarter’s GDP slump was a snow-induced blip.Output from firms fell 1.4 per cent in the month according to the Office for National Statistics, following the 0.1 per cent decline in March. City analysts had expected a 0.3 per cent expansion.It was the worst monthly performance since October 2012.The ONS added that there was “widespread weakness” in the sector, with nine of the 13 sub-sectors&nbspshowing a decline.The wider industrial sector, which includes energy firms, saw an 0.8 per cent fall, following a 0.1 per cent expansion in March.The Deputy Bank of England Governor Dave Ramsden said last week that recent survey data was supporting the Bank’s view that GDP growth would bounce back strongly in the second quarter.But the latest report on manufacturing, which accounts for 10 per cent of UK GDP, suggests otherwise. The pound fell sharply in the wake of the figures, dropping to $1.3373, down 0.3 per cent on the day, as traders scaled back their bets on an August interest rate hike from the Bank.Construction output was also weaker than expected according to the ONS, growing by just 0.5 per cent, following the 2.3 per cent slump in March.Rounding off a hat-trick of disappointing news, the ONS separately reported that the goods trade deficit was wider than expected in April at £14.03bn, rather than the £11.35bn City analysts had pencilled in.On a three monthly basis the value of goods exports, excluding erratics, was down 3.7 per cent, while imports fell 2 per cent“It is possible that the UK is now moving past the recent sweet spot for exporters, with growth in key markets moderating and the impact of the post-EU referendum slump in sterling, which has helped some exporters, subsiding. The possibility of an escalating trade war has added to the downside risks for exporters,” said Suren&nbspThiru&nbspof the British Chambers of Commerce.The ONS’s analysis of the weakness of the economy in 2018 has been at odds with the Bank of England’s, with the statistics agency identifying underlying weakness, but the Bank attributing the slowdown almost entirely to the “Beast from the East” snowstorms of February and March.The Bank held off from raising interest rates in May, saying that it would wait to see if its more optimistic view would be bourne out.In the first quarter GDP growth is estimated to have slumped to just 0.1 per cent, with manufacturing growing by 0.2 per cent, services by 0.3 per cent and constriction slumping by 2.7 per cent.The National Institute of Economic and Social Research (Niesr) estimated on Monday&nbspthat the UK's GDP growth rate was still only 0.2 per cent in the three months to May.or register with your social accountAlready have an account? title: brexit news theresa may house of lords amendments customs union single market EU
story: Mrs May will rally up her troops tonight for a powerful speech she hopes will prompt them to come together and reject 15 amendments by Peers to the Brexit orce bill which are up for debate in the Commons tomorrow and Wednesday.It will be the biggest challenge yet for the Prime Minister, whose wafer-thin Commons majority threatens to keep Britain shackled to Brussels.Senior Conservatives have also urged their party to get behind the Brexit strategy of Mrs May, who tonight will meet the backbench 1922 Committee to stress the importance of scrapping the amendments.Should MPs insist on keeping some of the Lords amendments it would spell disaster for Mrs May, who could struggle to get a Brexit deal locked in with the EU before Autumn.The most crucial of amendment is the so-called &lsquoMeaningful vote&rsquo which will take place tomorrow afternoon.Mrs May will rally up her troops tonight for a powerful speechMrs May is looking toward Labour’s Brexit-backing MPs such as Kate Hoey, Frank Field and John MannA yes vote would see Parliament take control of negotiations if a final Brexit deal is turned down by MPs.Tonight she will tell fellow Tories: &ldquoThe purpose of the EU Withdrawal Bill is simple - it is putting EU legislation into law to ensure a smooth and orderly transition as we leave.But the message we send to the country through our votes this week is important. We must be clear that we are united as a party in our determination to deliver on the decision made by the British people.They want us to deliver on Brexit and build a brighter future for Britain as we take back control of our money, our laws and our borders.Mrs May&rsquos pleas for unity come in the wake of a cluster of remain-backing MPs, led by Anna Soubry, a former business minister, and ex attorney general Dominic Grieve, who have demanded a Brexit that keeps Britain in the single market and customs union.Boris Johnson said he wanted a more “macho” approach to BrexitAs a result, Mrs May is looking toward Labour&rsquos Brexit-backing MPs such as Frank Field, Kate Hoey, John Mann, Graham Stringer, Roger Godsiff and Kevin Hopkins whose votes on the debate could give her the support she so desperately needs to overturn the Lords&rsquo ruling.The Prime Minister&rsquos pledge follows a series of blows she faced last week.One was Brexit Secretary David Davis enlisting the help of MPs Steve Baker and Suella Braverman to form a triple resignation pact after Mrs May infuriated him by showing a revised plan for avoiding a hard border with Northern Ireland to remain-supporting ministers first, in an attempt to keep them on side.The new plan would have kept the UK tied to the EU for a &ldquotime limited period should she fail to reach a customs deal.A yes vote would see Parliament take control of negotiationsAdded to that, Home Secretary newbie Savid Javid tore up plans to offer European migrants preferential access to Britain after Brexit, which angered Mrs May&rsquos remain-backing ministers.Boris Johnson piled on more stress for Mrs May when it was leaked that he wanted a more &ldquomacho approach to Brexit, adding the UK was on course to be &ldquonot in Europe, but run by Europe.

title: brexit news labour andy mcdonald kier starmer jeremy corbyn immigration
story: A Labour frontbencher claimed immigration could rise after BrexitJeremy Corbyn&rsquos shadow Transport Secretary Andy McDonald today raised questions on how committed the party was on bringing immigration numbers down after saying businesses were &ldquocrying out for more workers.Speaking on BBC Radio 5 Live, Mr McDonald said: &ldquoYour immigration levels should be consistent with the needs of your economy. Now whether that means going down or going up.&ldquoLots of sectors do say they need people, businesses are absolutely crying out, if you cut off the supply of oxygen, supply of labour that we need to sustain our businesses, you're going to cause us major problems and put us out of business in some circumstances.&ldquoSo let's just be sensible and adult about it, we need people into these sectors and that must continue, whichever way you look at this it'd be ludicrous to do otherwise.Shadow Transport Secretary Andy McDonald suggested immigration could rise post-BrexitMr McDonald&rsquos comments come after shadow Brexit Secretary Sir Keir Starmer yesterday hinted on the BBC Andrew Marr Show bringing down levels of immigration would not be a priority for Labour.He said: &ldquoWe are facing up to that. We would have to negotiate on the four freedoms, freedom of movement. We need to set out what we want.&ldquoSo we need to spell out what actually we are asking for whilst negotiating with the EU against a changing backdrop.Brexit minister Suella Braverman, who joined fellow minister Steve Baker and Brexit Secretary David Davis in a resignation pact to stop Theresa May keeping the UK tied to the customs union, slammed Labour for breaking a promise to respect the referendum result.shadow Brexit Secretary Sir Keir Starmer yesterday hinted immigration was not a priority for LabourShe said: &ldquoKeir Starmer has today confirmed that Labour's amendment to the Withdrawal Bill could mean accepting free movement and continuing to follow a swathe of EU rules with absolutely no say in them.&ldquoThis shows Labour have no interest in controlling our borders and are breaking all their promises to respect the referendum result.She added: &ldquoOnly the Conservatives will get the best deal for the whole country &ndash delivering on the referendum vote to get control of our money, borders and laws, while building a strong new relationship with Europe.

story: NSW opposition leader Luke Foley said he would alter the June public holiday to &ldquohonour the First Peoples of the State if he is elected to Government in the NSW state elections due to be acknowledge the special place the First Peoples occupy in the story of our state and nation.&ldquoNSW should have a public holiday which recognises and celebrates 60,000 years of Indigenous history here.Luke Foley (R) has called for New South Wales to acknowledge Australia's Indigenous history                The reasons Queen Elizabeth WILL NEVER give up her throne REVEALED                Queen uses iPad to watch her foals being born Queen Elizabeth last visited Australia during her tour of the country in October 2011Prince Charles visited Gove in Australia's Northern Territory during his tour in AprilHe added the Aboriginal flag would fly above the Sydney Harbour Bridge throughout the year as a &ldquosymbol of respect and pride for the First Peoples.Mr Foley&rsquos party would likely wait until the end of the Queen&rsquos reign before formalising the new public holiday, and would consult the local population regarding the precise timing of the change.The British Royal Family is nevertheless still strongly committed to Australia, and Prince Charles and the Duchess of Cornwall visited the country in April for the opening of the 2018 Gold Coast Commonwealth Games.Prince Harry and Meghan Markle are also due to visit the country, along with Fiji, New Zealand and Tonga, in October for the opening of the Invictus Games.Shadow Minister for Aboriginal Affairs David Harris said changing the focus of the public holiday would provide the next step towards reconciliation and offer vital recognition of indigenous populations.He said: &ldquoCreating an Indigenous public holiday in NSW is a small step we can take to acknowledge the past but more importantly create a meaningful way forward.&ldquoIt&rsquos important for us to build on the existing relationship with the NSW Aboriginal community to empower them to achieve lasting generational change.Mr Foley also announced he is committed to negotiating a treaty between the Government and NSW&rsquos Aboriginal population.The parade marks the official birthday of the Sovereign, even though the Queen's actual birthday is on April 21st.                    REUTERS1 of 66Britain's Queen Elizabeth, along with other members of the British royal familyThe lower house of Victoria&rsquos state Government also voted just last week in favour of negotiating an Aboriginal treaty.There is growing concern that Australia Day on January 26 is not inclusive of indigenous Australians, but rather acts as a reminder of the day they lost their land and culture through colonisation.ANTaR website commented on the issue, stating: &ldquoCelebrating it ignores the truths of our shared history and is akin to asking Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to celebrate their own invasion and dispossession.At the heart of reconciliation is an acceptance of the history of past injustices to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

story: The furious radio host said the 52 percent of Brexit-voting Britons &ldquolost out last week when Prime Minister Theresa May proposed a backstop arrangement which could effectively keep the UK closely tied to the EU after Brexit if no solution is found to the Irish border.&nbspSpeaking on BBC Sunday Politics, Ms Hartley-Brewer said: &ldquoIt seems that every time that there is some sort of fundamental clash between Remain and Leave within the Cabinet &ndash&nbspit&rsquos Remain that ends up winning.Brexiteer MPs hit out at the Government after the Prime Minister proposed a backstop arrangement to resolve the Irish border issue which could keep the UK closely aligned to Brussels after Brexit.The backstop draft sets out a blueprint for a temporary customs partnership if the technology for a &ldquofrictionless border is not prepared in time for the end of the Brexit transition period in December 2020.Getty&bullBBCBrexit news: Julia Hartley-Brewer said Brexiteers Brexit Secretary David Davis had threatened to resign if the backstop proposal was time-limited.Mrs May's proposed December 2021 date, a year after the transition ends, is an aspirational promise to have a new arrangement in place in order to replace the temporary backstop before 2022 &ndash over six years after Britain voted to leave the EU.Ms Hartley-Brewer said David Davis &ldquoblinked and the backstop fudge has &ldquono legal meaning whatsoever.The radio host warned there could be consequences if MPs do not follow the wishes of Brexit voters. She said: &ldquoThe reality is that everyone in the Tory party is so scared of having a Tory leadership contest &ndash so scared of being forced somehow into a general election and Jeremy Corbyn winning that they are not willing to risk anything.&ldquoThey&rsquoll win the votes on the EU Withdrawal Bill, the House of Lords amendments. Yet again, as with everything to do with Brexit, they push the fudge further and further down the road.&ldquoAt some point, we are either going to be leaving or we are not going to be leaving in a meaningful way.&ldquoIt is all very well saying they want to protect themselves now but the Leave voters are going to punish the political party that doesn&rsquot deliver Brexit.Former Ukip leader and Brexiteer Nigel Farage warned Britain will be in an even worse position after Brexit if it remains closely aligned to the EU&rsquos customs union after Brexit.The Conservative MP is known for his upper-class mannerisms and traditionalist views                    AFPGetty Images1 of 10Mr Farage warned Britons will not get &ldquoany form of Brexit until six years after the UK has left the EU.He said: We will finish up perhaps in an even worse place than we are now because we won't be free to de-regulate, we won't be free to go out in the world and make our own deals, we won't be controlling our own borders and we will still be accepting rules from Brussels.On Friday, the EU&rsquos chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier rejected the proposal and argued that the proposed backstop would only be feasible for Northern Ireland and not the whole of the UK.Mr Barnier said: Let me be very clear. Our backstop cannot be extended to the whole of the United Kingdom.It has been designed for the specific situation of Northern Ireland. The temporary backstop is not in line with what we want.

title: brexit news britain france technology leader google facebook amazon theresa may macron
story: Britain could be dethroned as the European technology leader amid concerns around BrexitThis is according to industry insiders speaking to Politico, who outlined contrasting strategies by London and Paris in dealings with startups, venture capitalists and Silicon Valley&rsquos biggest names.They claimed the British Government&rsquos focus on leaving the EU has seen many of its ties with the technology sector downgraded, with reduced access to senior officials.In France, President Emmanuel Macron has led a regulatory drive that has seen the rewriting of domestic legislation, including local labour laws and making demands that global tech companies pay more tax.This has led many high-profile executives, such as Facebook&rsquos Mark Zuckerberg and Amazon&rsquos Jeff Bezos, visit Paris in an attempt to woo Mr Macron, including via announcements for new research centres and jobs in the country.Fr&eacuted&eacuteric Court, a French venture capitalist who as a partner of Felix Capital, invested in billion-euro EU startups like Deliveroo, said: &ldquoIn the past 10 years, there&rsquos been amazing work done to make London the centre of the European tech ecosystem, but with Brexit, that has stopped.                Minister calls for 'spark of genius' to ignite post-Brexit success                EU will PAY: Galileo satellite may NOT happen after Brussels BULLYING&ldquoThe momentum has shifted to Paris. There&rsquos now more pace there than in London. That was unthinkable even two years ago.According to data provider Dealroom, French venture capitalists raised a record &pound2.4 billion last year - higher than the UK's &pound2.2 billion.But despite the uncertainty of Brexit, international backers invested a record &pound6.4 billion into the British tech sector last year - treble the amount earmarked for French competitors.Roxanne Varza, director of Station F, a startup incubator in Paris that has partnered with the likes of Facebook and French bank BNP Pribas, conceded: &ldquoWhen companies want to raise more than &euro30 million, they still have to leave France.Following Britain&rsquos decision to leave the EU in 2016, tech insiders claimed their access to the UK Government was immediately shut off.Google is making attempts to increase its presence in France They added that former Prime Minister David Cameron held monthly breakfasts with local startups and venture capitalists to gather their expertise, but these ground to a halt under Mrs May.Several executives speaking to Politico claimed companies - many of whom had overwhelmingly voted to remain in the EU - were kept at arm&rsquos length.Other difficulties included meeting with Government to address key concerns over Brexit, such as continued access to European tech workers and EU research and investment funds.Will Tanner, a former deputy head of Mrs May&rsquos policy unit, said: &ldquoWhat has changed is there is a lack of special treatment for tech.&ldquoThe government is concentrating on lots of different sectors in the economy.Mr Macron has moved quickly to take advantage of this growing uncertainty and just a month after winning the country&rsquos presidency in May 2017, unveiled a series of tech programmes aimed at attracting international companies and talent to France.He also unveiled a &euro10 billion national innovation fund and plans to streamline the country&rsquos corporate tax and labour laws to make it easier for companies to recruit staff.By the end of this year, Google is opening an artificial intelligence research centre in Paris and Amazon will double its local workforce to 7,500 employees.Entrepreneur Gilles Babinet, who represents France in the Digital Champions Group within the EU, said: &ldquoNot many heads of state have put digital issues at the heart of their action.&ldquoMacron is out there selling France as a hub for artificial intelligence. Every time he goes to a foreign country, he&rsquos making the pitch personally.

title: Emmanuel Macron news economic advisors revolt over policies
story: ALAMYFrench President Emmanuel Macron speaks during a press conference in La Malbaie, CanadaThe memo&rsquos accusatory tone is the latest sign of discord between Mr Macron and the centre-left supporters who propelled him to power last year by voting for the politically inexperienced ex-banker over far-right veteran Marine Le Pen.In the confidential memo sent to Mr Macron&rsquos office on June 4, top economists Philippe Aghion, Philippe Martin and Jean Pisani-Ferry said that the president&rsquos economic policy and &ldquoemancipatory ambition was failing to convince citizens, including his &ldquomost fervent supporters, according to French newspaper Le Monde.&ldquoMany supporters of the then-candidate fear a shift to the right, motivated by the temptation to occupy the political space neglected by a conservative party in crisis, the economists wrote, referring to the country&rsquos embattled Les R&eacutepublicains party.Mr Macron, who has pitched himself as &ldquoneither left nor right, loosened France&rsquos rigid labour rules and slashed a controversial wealth tax within his first six months in office &ndash decisions which have earned him the unflattering nickname &ldquopresident of the rich.                Italian advisor takes a pop at EU over migrant boat criticism                Brexit concerns could see Britain DETHRONED by France as EU tech le...Economists Philippe Aghion, Philippe Martin and Jean Pisani-FerryThe young centrist was elected on a promise to deeply transform the French economy, but his supporters are growing increasingly weary of his right-leaning reform agenda.The three economists warned him that there was a risk the French would find such measures unfair, and think that the government is &ldquoindifferent to the social question and to the needs of the poorest members of society.&ldquoThe need to address inequalities, a key issue that helped shape the candidate&rsquos political identity, has been completely ignored, they argued, adding that that the president &ldquomust talk about the issue of inequalities and not leave this debate to his opponents.Among the proposals to reduce inequalities, the economists suggested a rise in inheritance tax for the richest, slashing tax credits on property investments, and scrapping a pledge to get rid of a housing tax for the wealthiest 20 per cent.The economists said that while &ldquoimportant actions had been taken by the Macron administration in the past year, some had &ldquofallen short of initial ambitions.Mr Pisani-Ferry, a university professor at Paris&rsquo Sciences Po university who coordinated Mr Macron&rsquos economic programme, declined to comment when contacted by Reuters.Mr Martin, a former Macron adviser and the head of France&rsquos Council of Economic Analysis (CAE), and Mr Aghion of the prestigious Coll&egravege de France, did not immediately respond to a request for comment, Reuters said.A spokesperson for Mr Macron&rsquos office confirmed it had received the note, but said that it was not indicative of the government&rsquos economic policy.

title: national living wage uk 2018 increase minimum wage 16 18 25 year old
story: But the amount is still below the Real Living Wage, a voluntary scheme to which thousands of employers including retailers, local authorities and charities have got involved.The National Living Wage is the amount of money all employees aged over 25 are legally entitled to.It used to be known as the National Minimum Wage, but it was re-branded in 2016.The National Living Wage increased from £7.50 to £7.83 for those aged 25 and over.The 33 pence-an-hour rise was introduced on Sunday April 1, 2018.The compulsory National Living Wage was introduced in 2016.The first National Minimum Wage was set in 1998 by the Labour government.Mr Hammond is aiming to get the wage to £9 by 2020.The National Minimum Wage is the amount which workers aged under 25, but of school-leaving age, are entitled to.However, the amount differs depending on age and whether the worker is on an apprenticeship scheme.Workers aged 21-24 were paid £7.05 - and it went up to £7.38 from April 1, 2018.The wage increased from £5.60 to £5.90 for 18 to 20-year-olds, and from £4.05 to £4.20 for under 18s.However, apprentices were only entitled to £3.50 if they are under-19 - this increased to £3.70 from April 1, 2018.In April 2018, the minimum wage for 25-year-olds rose from £7.50 to £7.83 an hour.The national limits are legally binding.Anyone who thinks they are not getting the National Living Wage or National Minimum Wage should complain to their employer in the first instance.If this does not get anywhere, the next step is to take the complaint to HMRC who will investigate.Those who are self-employed, voluntary workers, company directors and family members who live in the home of the employer and do household chores do not qualify for either rate.There is no difference in pay for those that live in London compared to elsewhere.The only discrepancy is for people working in agriculture or horticulture.Workers already employed before October 1, 2013 are entitled to the pay set under their contract of employment.This is a voluntary scheme aiming to recognise the actual cost of living, to which 3,000 employers have signed up.Under it, the lowest rate of pay is calculated according to the cost of living in the UK based on the changing cost of a basket of groceries.The amount is set by the charity Living Wage Foundation, and accredited employers include local authorities, NHS trusts, banks, retailers, charities and construction companies.The foundations calculations put the real Living Wage at £8.75 an hour - and £10.20 in London.These rates also apply to over-18s in recognition that young people face the same living costs as everyone else.And while companies are not legally entitled to pay more than the National Living and Minimum Wages, those which have signed up to the real Living Wage scheme have pledged to pay all workers those rates.The rate is calculated every November, and accredited employers are committed to any increases.While theres no legal obligation for your employer to pay you more than the National Living Wage (£7.50 from April 1, 2017), if your company is accredited by the Living Wage Foundation you should be receiving more than that.The foundations head of partnerships Graham Griffiths said anyone concerned can use their online whistleblowing service, and any employer not adhering to the Real Living Wage faced losing its accreditation.Graham said one area where it was challenging to pay the living wage were retail and hospitality but pointed to Ikea, Aldi and Lidl, which have agreed to pay the same rate.The scheme was launched in 2001 by parents in East London, and the foundation was set up in 2011.In 2005 following a growing interest from employers, the Greater London Authority established the Living Wage Unit to calculate what the lowest pay should ideally be.In 2008 Trust for London selected the scheme as a special initiative and made a grant of more than £1million to campaign for it and set up an accreditation scheme for employers.In April 2016 it became the inspiration for the governments higher minimum wage rate, which it rebranded the National Living Wage.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: dont hide your demons behind a smile like kate spade or anthony bourdain ask for help
story: Frances Beatrix, known as Bea, is just 13 and having to come to terms with the fact that her mum Kate Spade took her own life.Then there is 11-year-old Ariane Bourdain, whose father, travel and food writer Anthony Bourdain, was found dead in his Paris hotel room yesterday in an apparent suicide.Kate Spade reportedly left a note for her daughter which read: “Bea, I have always loved you. This is not your fault. Ask Daddy!”Can you imagine how that little girl must be feeling?She’s lost her mother and some have surmised the note appears to point the finger at her dad.It’s obviously not at all clear if that was really Kate’s intention, or whether she just wanted her daughter to seek answers and comfort from her father.That’s the trouble with suicide. Those left behind have to deal with so many unanswered questions.Look at little Ariane, who has just lost her beloved dad and will also be left with feelings of confusion and anger, as well as searing grief.Anthony, 61, was an award-winning chef and TV presenter.He was in France filming an episode of his successful CNN series, Parts Unknown, when he was found unresponsive in his hotel room.He was a larger-than-life, passionate character who championed the underdog and supported his girlfriend Asia Argento, one of the first actresses to accuse Harvey Weinstein of rape.Both Kate and Anthony were successful and, as far as the rest of the world was concerned, were living the dream.But no one really knows what goes on behind closed doors.Kate, who was 55, met husband Andy 35 years ago.They were married for 24 years but had been living apart for the past ten months, while sharing parental duties.They hadn’t discussed divorce and Andy said they still loved each other very much.He went on to say there was no indication that Kate was going to kill herself and his priority now is to protect and comfort his daughter.He will not only be grieving but inevitably feel he should have been able to somehow prevent this tragedy.People have asked “Who in their right mind would leave their own child to grow up motherless?”, but that’s the point.Kate wasn’t “in her right mind” and it seems neither was Anthony.People who kill themselves are suffering mental distress that no one can understand unless they have walked a mile in their shoes.On the surface, Kate had it all. Many thought she was still happily married. The couple had a healthy daughter, her designer label was a massive success.Kate was also good looking, funny and always seemed happy in interviews and photos. But now we know the poor woman was in agony.According to members of her family she had suffered from mental health problems for many years, and there has been speculation she was reluctant to seek help.If this was the case, then the reasons put forward for Kate trying to cope on her own are heartbreaking.She was apparently worried that her business, based on her cheerful handbags, would be affected if it was known she suffered from anxiety and depression. That really is desperately sad.Not only was Kate trying to cope with her demons but her marriage was going through a rocky patch and all the while she felt as though she had to paint on a smile and pretend everything was fine.Her life became so unbearable that she believed her only escape was to end it all.Her husband has said she was undergoing treatment and taking medication, yet Kate’s death shows that despite a change in attitudes towards those unfortunate enough to suffer from mental health problems, there is still a very long way to go.There are still people who will tell sufferers who are clearly very unwell to man up, or pull themselves together, which is just about the worst thing you could do.Suicide is a growing problem and each death is a tragedy. It is the biggest killer of men aged 20 to 49 in the UK. At least 84 men will have taken their own lives this week.If so many people were being lost to a virus there would be a national outcry and funds would be made available to find the cause and cure.Mental illness is still a Cinderella disease, and that cannot continue.But there are glimmers of hope.On TV we’ve seen the effect of Aidan Connor’s suicide on his friends and family in Coronation Street. It was tough to watch but raised awareness on a massive scale.We have seen raw grief but also deep anger and Aidan was branded selfish by his distraught sister.Those closest to him have experienced guilt because they didn’t realise how much pain he was in and have suffered sleepless nights and have been torturing themselves for not knowing how bad it was and for not offering help.Corrie shone a light in a dark place and I believe this storyline and the tragedy of Kate Spade and the apparent suicide of Anthony Bourdain will make people think.None of us knows what private battles are being fought against the dark demons of mental illness, even among our family and close friends.We all need to be watchful and unafraid to ask if everything really is OK. We need to be prepared to be rebuffed but to gently persist if we feel there is a real problem.The black despair that it seems Anthony Bourdain and Kate Spade succumbed to could happen to any one of us.If you feel depressed, please, I beg you, be brave and ask for help. And let’s all be prepared to reach out to that person in despair.I FIND it utterly ludicrous that in the eyes of the law a criminal who steals your pet is treated in exactly the same way as if they stole your TV or sofa.There’s no consideration for the fact that your dog or cat is a living, breathing animal and a much beloved member of the family.If the thieves are caught, although unlikely in these days of police cuts, the monetary value of the pet is the only consideration when it comes to sentencing.This is bonkers. You simply cannot put a price on your pet.So I am delighted that a campaign to change the law is gaining momentum.What all concerned dog and cat lovers want is higher sentencing for the theft of our animals and to reclassify stealing a pet as a crime in its own right.Hopefully this would act as a deterrent to pet theft, something alarmingly on the increase.One of those who passionately wants the law to change is Sir Bruce Forsyth’s daughter Debbie Matthews.Back in 2006, both her dogs were stolen from her car.She appeared on GMTV with her dad to make a heartfelt plea begging for the return of Yorkshire terriers Gizmo and Widget.Thankfully, within hours of appearing on the show, people who had bought the dogs in good faith at a market realised they were stolen from Debbie and she was emotionally reunited with them.It was a traumatic time for the whole family and Debbie knows she was incredibly lucky her story had a happy ending.So many owners never see their pets again and are left with endless worries about their fate.If you want to help change the law, do sign the pet theft petition at petition.parliament.uk/petitions/212174 and make your voice heard.IT was impossible to take the p*** out of Peter Stringfellow, because he would be first to make fun of himself.He knew his habit of wearing tiny thongs made him look daft, and was well aware that his mullet haircut was old-fashioned and silly and that people considered him to be a bit naff.When he was pilloried, he just gave one of his big guffaws and carried on enjoying himself.Peter was funny, kind-hearted and generous to a fault.He bore his illness with great stoicism and bravery and will be sadly missed.POLDARK returns to our screens tomorrow night amid a row over what many in Scotland refer to as “taps aff”.This occurs on those wonderful, albeit rare, occasions when the sunshine beams warmly north of the border and allows chaps to remove their cagoules, sweatshirts, woolly jumpers and tops.Aidan Turner, who plays Captain Poldark, is probably one of the most famous exponents of “taps aff” in recent times, ever since those sweaty scything scenes in his first series.It turns out that it was Aidan’s idea to take off his cambric shirt and scythe away in those tight breeches.But it’s caused the mother of all rows, with admiring women being accused of “objectifying” the bold captain.I have thoughtfully reproduced an image of a topless Aidan so you can make up your own minds.You will either think this photograph adds to the joy of a Saturday or be horrified by the sexualisation of the poor, unfortunate man.Frankly, I’m happy to wallow in this fantastic view and look forward to tomorrow, BBC1, 9pm, when I can enjoy some cracking writing, proper acting and top production values.Those “taps aff” scenes only enhance the pleasure of Poldark and, don’t forget, no one forced Aidan to show his pert nipples.He knows full well he’s a handsome fella and it was all his choice, for which we are truly grateful.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: muslim campaigner celebrates british muslims
story: Despite the killings, the country has remained resolutely united.Today, The Sun on Sunday and The Sun proudly begin a series of articles from inspirational British Muslims who are leading figures in our hospitals, the legal profession and sport.Campaigner Fiyaz Mughal founded Tell MAMA, a group supporting victims of anti-Muslim hate and allowing them to report their concerns, in 2012.Fiyaz, a social entrepreneur and also director of interfaith group Faith Matters, writes here as we proudly celebrate the British Muslims, who help make our nation great.IN 2017 Britain suffered an appalling spate of terrorist atrocities, culminating in a shocking anti-Muslim attack on Finsbury Park mosque almost exactly a year ago.The roots of this hatred go back a long way. I believe the horrifying murder of soldier Lee Rigby in May 2013 was a turning point.As the founder of Tell MAMA, I found myself in the unenviable position of having to mobilise my tiny team at the time to help the growing number of people being targeted at a street and online level by anti-Muslim hatred.The backlash was significant, given the targeting of a young soldier minding his own business and the brutal manner of the terrorist attack.In the aftermath, Ukrainian neo-Nazi Pavlo Lapshyn placed three bombs in mosques in Wolverhampton, Walsall and Tipton — two months after murdering Mohammed Saleem, a grandfather walking back home from his mosque in Birmingham.The past five years have seen no let-up in the UK.People acting alone and small insular cells of men, and increasingly women, have carried out attacks at London Bridge, in Manchester, Finsbury Park and Westminster Bridge.And let us not ­forget the multiple terrorist attacks on 7/7 and the attempted attacks on civilians on 21/7.Our country has had its fair share of local and national triggers for potential tensions, but the unique nature of British society has meant we have not seen riots on our streets, such as those in Oldham in 2001 — and this is something to be ­celebrated.Terrorist trigger points have clearly led to rises in anti-Muslim hate incidents and there have been points where our country has been under ­significant pressure.After 7/7 and the significant loss of life that took place then, Britain was on a heightened state of alert as another plot failed to deliver its deadly cargo and the police and security services were in a race to find members of that terror cell.Dubbed 21/7, the country was shaken, ­communities were fearful and there was a crackle in the air as some people aired their frustrations openly.Even after all of this, we as communities held together.There is therefore something unique in our country which means community violence has not broken out, whereas in other European ­countries there have been street clashes and the widespread intimidation of minority communities.That “uniqueness” in our country is based on the old tradition that is ingrained in our society — that of “live and let live”, and “fair play”.It also underscores that the space for the accommodation of ideas and new populations has been a fundamental and historic part of our country though today, with resource pressures, there are limits.However, this is not only one-way traffic, and a sense of pride and identity within groups such as Britain’s Muslims has shown itself time and time again.It is therefore important to note that while ­younger citizens are less proud to be English, poll after poll has shown that Muslims living here are more ­patriotic than the average Brit.This means many Muslims do feel pride in a country where they can worship freely, be who they want to be and have the ability to practice their faith how they want to.We also have to say what is patently obvious, that Muslims have more freedoms in the United Kingdom compared to their counterparts in ­mainland Europe, where veil bans, harassment and chronic unemployment blight Muslim and other minority communities.It is this freedom to worship without fear, allied to the British sense of fair play, that makes us a place many countries look up to.The fact is our futures are inter-related and will continue to be as people travel more and ­connect through social media.It also means many of our preconceptions of different communities will change over time.This can be a force for good, though hand-in-hand with this must be that there are a unique set of values in our country.They have held us together in the darkest moments and have strengthened our resolve to stand together. Of this, we can always be proud.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: theresa may must now show shes got the chops to lead global britain out of the eu
story: There is a worrying sense of drift in Downing Street.We haven’t seen enough on vital issues at home, and our negotiations with the EU are turning into such an expensive fudge you’d think Mrs May was setting up a sweet shop for the summer holidays.There are vital votes to be fought over this week in the Commons.Win or lose, some Tory rebels will be plotting her successor.The Prime Minister must show some leadership, face down Westminster’s remoaners, and deliver a Brexit that allows this country to thrive once we leave the European Union.She must prove that she — like the 17.4million people who voted for a brighter future outside the EU — believes in Britain and what it can be.There has to be more to Theresa May than just clinging on.WE’VE heard our fair share of terrible train excuses, but tunnel trouble is a new one.It is staggering that in the 21st century, Thameslink have to change drivers in order to go through a small tunnel, as if North London has turned into Narnia.But funny as it seems, every delay matters. Not just because it holds the economy back, but because it gives privatisation a bad name.Putting the railways back into public ownership would be a complete disaster, but it is no surprise that the idea is becoming more popular.Transport supremo Chris Grayling looks derailed. His decision to sign off Thameslink’s fines for this year before they’d even run the trains is barking.He needs to get our trains back on track.BRITAIN is in the grip of a crime wave and Sajid Javid must get on top of it.The Home Secretary’s first priority should be to listen to our Beat the Blades taskforce, who today lay out their manifesto for knife-free streets.A Government that doesn’t keep the public safe has failed its most fundamental duty.The build-up to the World Cup has been more political than ever.But it is time to put that to one side. Whoever you support, enjoy the football.Who knows, it may end 52 years of hurt…Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: uk weather drought three month heatwave june august world cup
story: However, the extreme heat has also sparked fears of a drought as the country looks to swelter in the heat between late June and August.However, the current high temperatures and unseasonal lack of rainfall has already started becoming a cause for concern in parts of the country, with parts of the Lake District already drying up.Photos from Sunday show how drastically low water levels have become at Thirlmere Reservoir near the market town of Keswick, following limited rainfall across the North West of England in past weeks.Sun worshippers are likely to get a taste the impending heatwave in the early part of this week with sub-tropical air from the Azores warming things up with highs of 23C and bright sunshine in the south.Later in the week though showers are expected in the north-west with a European monsoon expected.The Weather Company predicted temperatures would soar to 33C from late June, making the summer the hottest since 2006.Met Office records show Britain’s average summer temperature is 14.3C.There is double the usual probability of this summer having a higher temperature than 2013’s 15.17C - which would make 2018 the warmest summer since 2006 - the hottest summer for a century.The hot weather is set to arrive as the UK gears up for the World Cup and Wimbledon.Bookmakers Ladbrokes cut odds on summer being the hottest on record to the shortest odds ever offered – just 5/2.Spokesman Alex Apati said: “Punters and weathermen believe Britain will wilt. Odds on a record summer are shorter than ever.”The Met Office is warning emergency services, transport leaders, business chiefs and councils of the risks of a hotter-than-normal three months ahead.Britain is set to wilt due to high pressure, which brings hot and dry conditions, the Met Office said.Last year saw grim school holidays spoil summer, summer 2014 was ruined by rain following ex-Hurricane Bertha, and 2012 had the wettest summer for 100 years.But 2009 was a hot summer – and the 2006 summer sizzler saw a peak of 36.5C on July 19, at Wisley, Surrey.The Met Office June-August forecast said: “For June-August, above-average temperatures are more likely than below-average temperatures.“The probability the UK average temperature for June-August will fall into the warmest of our five categories is 40 percent.“The coldest of our five categories is around 5 percent.“The likelihood of above-average temperatures is greater than usual. The Met Office long-range prediction system shows a slightly increased chance of high-pressure patterns across the UK.”The Weather Outlook forecaster Brian Gaze said: “The warmest summer since 2006 is a possibility, after recent years saw a series of disappointing summers.“The June to August period only needs to be 1C above average for it to happen.”Leon Brown, head of meteorological operations at The Weather Channel, owned by The Weather Company, said: “33C is expected by early July as heat from high pressure over Britain builds.”Met Office forecaster Helen Roberts said: “Theres plenty of sunshine to come this week, with the South generally fine through the week, although the North-West will be changeable from Wednesday.“There is a signal for a gradual return to more settled weather through the end of June. Temperatures are likely to be warmer than average, with the possibility of very warm or hot spells.”

title: worlds largest skinny dip ireland guiness world record
story: The women - all aged from their late teens to mid-80s - took over a secluded beach in County Wicklow in Ireland in the hopes of a charity record bid.Many of the 2,505 participants were cancers survivors who used the mass naked swim as a means to overcome self-confidence issues related to mastectomy scars.Organisers of the record-breaking stunt have hailed it “an empowering experience in the fight against cancer.”Collectively, the nude bathers smashed a record previously held by Australian skinny dippers in Perth - despite the water temperature being about 10 degrees colder in Ireland.The group of 2,505 women also managed to raise more than 275,000 Euros for Irish cancer charity, Aoibheanns Pink Tie.Organiser Dee Featherstone, who led yesterdays naked charge into the Irish Sea, said the numbers exceeded her wildest dreams.She said: I thought we might get 1,500 but it just got bigger and bigger.The whole beach was just awash with us - it was just incredible.Half the people who were there either had cancer or were affected by cancer or were supporting somebody or remembering someone who had cancer - every woman had their own little story of why they did it.It was very empowering.In Brighton, East Sussex, an estimated 550 people took part in the citys fourth annual Naked Bike Ride.They made their way through the town centre and along the seafront to Hove.The event is staged to raise awareness for road safety.The cyclists strip off to symbolise how vulnerable riders are on Britains buys roads.Some women joined in the craze for glitter boobs - plastering their chests with sparkling paint.She added that a lot of women had been nervous about baring all, due to scars left by cancer operations.Dee said: On the day absolutely nobody cared and the people who would have been really scared and nervous about doing it - they were the ones who were in the water longest and naked longest on the beach.They went in one sort of women and came out another sort of women - everyone has said that to me since.

title: pm needs to show some iron
story: She will probably win vital Brexit votes in the House of Commons.But that won’t mean much if she can’t get a grip on her party and on our future outside the EU. It is staggering that, almost two years after the referendum, ministers are still contradicting each other on TV about everything from the customs “backstop” to the Irish border.The Government’s failure to properly prepare for a “no deal” scenario is equally concerning.The PM must lead from the top. She should confirm this week what she wants from Brussels — no ifs, no buts and no more compromises.If EU bosses think we’re not ready to go it alone, they’ll offer us the thinnest gruel — and we’ll have to take it. They’re already warning that if we want a trade agreement we’ll have to accept free movement. That would be a betrayal of those who voted to take back control of our laws and borders from Brussels.We must be in a strong enough position at the negotiating table that we’re willing to walk away. The Prime Minister has shown admirable backbone in the past, taking on the policing unions as Home Secretary and in her robust response to terrorism.We need to see more of that politician — speaking up for Brexit voters in battles with Brussels and leading her party in Westminster.The chaos we’ve seen in recent months doesn’t just imperil our departure from the EU. It makes the prospect of a Jeremy Corbyn Government more likely.Time for Mrs May to show some Iron.THE “Visit Rwanda” adverts on Arsenal’s shirts next year are a black mark on the beautiful game.Our report today shows just how vicious Paul Kagame, the African nation’s bloodthirsty dictator, can be.It is a mystery to us why the UK Government continues to put money in his pockets — knowing full well that he runs a totalitarian state. Arsenal should think carefully about who they’re getting into bed with.And we shouldn’t send him another penny of taxpayers’ money.WHEN celebrities’ bad behaviour is splashed all over social media, it makes no sense that newspapers are sometimes held to different standards.One of Britain’s most senior judges agrees, saying that legal blocks that stop us reporting on some public figures are wrong when the briefest of internet searches reveals the truth.A free Press shouldn’t be muzzled by outdated laws.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: pm ambush to accept free movement
story: A European ambassador told the Sunday Times that EU Brexit chief Michel Barnier is planning to exploit the PM’s weakness ahead of the Tory party conference in the autumn to put the flagship EU open borders policy back on the negotiating table. Hewill demand Britain continues to accept freedom of movement in exchange for unfettered access to Europe’s single market. But the Migration Watch think tank warned Mrs May that failure to curb EU migration after Brexit would destroy the Tory party’s credibility with voters.Its boss Lord Green said: “Controlling our borders must mean reducing immigration or it is pointless. 62% want to see a reduction in low skilled migration while 80% of EU migrants over the last ten years have been lower skilled. So any new arrangements must involve a sharp cut in immigration from the EU or the credibility of the Conservative government will be in shreds.”And Jacob Rees-Mogg, leader of the powerful backbench European Research Group of Tory MPs, said the ambush would only backfire on the EU. He told The Sun: “If Brussels wants to do that it fails to realise why we voted to leave in the first place - it’s all about taking back control.“Clever ambushes are are yesterday’s story for the European Commission and they need to stop thinking along those lines. Their failure to do so is why Italy is unhappy, Hungary and so on. It’s a mindset that is actually turning nations against the European Union.”Meanwhile on Wednesday Home Secretary Sajid Javid is expected to announce the Government’s plans for the status of EU migrants already living in the UK. He has torn up plans by his predecessor Amber Rudd to offer preferential treatment to EU citizens after Brexit.Yesterday Labour frontbencher Andy McDonald said immigration could actually go up after Brexit. The shadow transport secretary Andy McDonald said if businesses wanted more people to be allowed into Britain then the Government should allow that. His comments were described by one Tory MP as a “kick in the teeth for Brexit voters”.And his shadow cabinet colleague Sir Keir Starmer also hinted Labour is getting ready to U-turn on their pledge to end free movement. Mr McDonald told Pienaar’s Politics on BBC Radio 5 Live: “Your immigration levels should be consistent with the needs of your economy. Now whether that means going down or going up.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: late night cramming does harm
story: Findings from the new study suggest that staying up late to try to memorise the information has the opposite effect, giving the brain no ‘downtime’ to let the knowledge sink in.Researchers from the Loyola Marymount University in California also found the sleep deprivation corresponded to lower exam scores.It suggests that new memories only stick in the brain if they are ‘consolidated ‘which is a process that largely happens during sleep.Scientists also examined the power of napping to boost memory after studying and found that newly learnt facts stuck in peoples brains better after a nap.Sara Alger, of Notre Dame University, Indiana, said “We demonstrated the importance of obtaining sleep soon after learning for superior consolidation of emotional memories, an effect that was robustly seen across young and, for the first time, middle-aged adults.”At the Cheltenham Science Festival last week, University College London professor of neuroscience Sarah-Jayne Blakemore, who is studying the teenage brain, called for schools to start later so youngsters would not have to get out of bed so early in the morning.In her new book, Inventing Ourselves: The Secret Life of the Teenage Brain, Blakemore said: “Forcing teenagers to go to school early in the morning ... is depriving them of sleep, which inhibits learning and lowers mood. School start times should be later for teenagers.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
